p: Dengue virus (DENV) causes a considerable burden to public health worldwide, consisting of 60 to 100 million symptomatic infections, 14,000 to 20,000 deaths per year, and of a global annual cost of about 9 billion dollars [ 1, 2]. Four distinct DENV serotypes exist; infection by one of them confers life-long immunity to that serotype and temporary cross-immunity to others. However, secondary dengue infections with different serotypes are more likely to cause severe illness because of an immune process known as antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE), where pre-existing cross-reacting antibodies do not neutralize but rather enhance viral replication [ 3].
